awd_titl_txt: NRI: Liquid Handling Robots - A New Paradigm for STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Robotics Initiative project will test a series of liquid handling robots in school biology and chemistry classes to determine the range of learning opportunities that can be supported through the instructional use of collaborative robots.  Low-cost robots using the Lego Mindstorms platform will be used to implement classroom activities ranging from artistic expression using colorful arrangements of liquids to performing experiments using dilution series, density gradients, and spectral measurements. The aim is to make biotechnology more tangible and relevant to students while supporting interdisciplinary learning as recommended by the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). This innovative approach to engaging students in biology and chemistry will be tested with teachers and students in grades 6-12, with a range of user studies being employed to examine learning outcomes and guide the development process.  The goal is to integrate liquid handling into educational robotics to enhance current science curricula by enabling deeper inquiry, more variety in learning experiences, and increased attention to interdisciplinary and project-based education.

The research of this project will focus on two themes:  students' sense making as they engage in inquiry activities using the platform, and the pedagogical and infrastructural support needed for sustainable deployment and implementation.  Multimodal data collected from students running experiments will be combined with traditional qualitative and quantitative methods to answer three primary questions related to the two research themes: 1) How effectively does the system capture the practices and inquiry activities of real scientists using similar tools?  2) How do the affordances identified by the first question map onto the learning goals of engaging in extended inquiry cycles within the context of limited amounts of time available to 6-12 grade science teachers? And 3) What implementation challenges are associated with our proposed curricular distribution model which relies on software and instructions being downloaded and fabricated in local Makerspaces or Lego/Arduino kits being used in schools?  The research plan for the project will progress over three years from Microgenetic design and testing during the first year to controlled study of in-class effectiveness during year 2.  In the final year of the project, teacher-led in-class effectiveness will be examined.

LHR Project Outcomes Report

Goals

The Liquid Handling Robot is an open-source DIY low-cost robot for automating scientific experiments, featuring an inexpensive Arduino microcontroller and plastic laser cut parts. It can be programmed in Snap4Arduino, a block-based programming language, which makes it suitable for beginner programmers. The robot was designed to be compatible with standard plasticware used in biological experiments (e.g., 96-well plates and cuvettes). This project?s goal was to bring the liquid handling robot platforms into schools, test them with teachers and students, iterate and advance our technology and lesson designs, and explore and develop wider dissemination plans. We envision that this work will promote learning and excitement in grades 6-12 and college by integrating the life sciences, chemistry, computational literacy, and mechatronics in the science classroom via low-cost, continuous access to a versatile, sophisticated set of experiments.

Cycles of design and development

Our design and development process includes several cycles in two main domains:

The engineering domain

This domain comprises the development of a DIY low-cost liquid handling robot. The robot?s general design used open-source DIY laser-cut parts, fully compatible with standard plasticware (96-well plates, cuvettes).

These DIY robots were distinct from our previously published Lego robots in the following designs: The cost in parts is ~$150 - and we estimate that a future mass-market product could be ~$100 or less. The robot can be programmed through many different platforms, including the block-based one we developed. Block-based programming enables much more accessible user interfaces and accessible to different age groups.

The robot can be fabricated or assembled by the students (i.e., would enable incorporation to maker activities) and can in the future be modified in an open-source manner by schools and other DIY designers. Also, the integration of a camera and many future modifications within the Arduino landscape are possible. We developed two versions of this robot: the first included three 3 motors. The 3-axis robot can only address containers along one dimension ? but we provided the students with a simple mechanism to access the fourth dimension by hand. The second version includes 4 motors moving into 4 axis ? which might be suitable for older learners. The three-axis design has reduced complexity ? but is a bit more limited in the types of experiments that can be done. We also developed the corresponding block-based user interface that allows students to use and program this robot. We characterize the precision/accuracy and durability. The robot designs are robust for at least 1-week (24h/day) usage without interruption and did not show any problems. The robot was also tested with and evaluated by teachers and students (next section.)

The Educational domain

A pilot study was conducted in a public middle school in the San Francisco Bay Area (USA). It included eleven 6th grade students (7 male and 4 female students) as part of an elective class. We designed a five-day curriculum, where students programmed the robot to help them experiment on the topic of acidity/alkalinity/pH. Students were asked to maintain a swimming pool?s ?cleanliness,? then taught about chlorine?s function in the process, and introduced to the concepts of pH, alkalinity, acidity, and the use of phenol red as an indicator to measure pH. Their task was to translate the pseudocode they wrote for the robot to handle their experiment on paper into real code that would be used to program the LHR with the hypothetical goal of sanitizing swimming pool water and maintaining a healthy pH.

In our design, we aimed to position students as scientists by directly experiencing how technological advances can accelerate scientific research. Also, we introduced the idea of coding the procedures of a science experiment through programming. Lastly, we aimed to develop students? understanding of chemistry concepts (pH, alkalinity, acidity, and the use of phenol red) and teach students to utilize an LHR to execute a scientific experiment. In this study, we demonstrated that students improved their understanding of algorithmic thinking and generalization following their use of the LHR. Students saw the benefits of integrating coding and science and using a robot to carry out a scientific experiment. They articulated the precision and time-saving benefits of using computational thinking through coding when conducting a science experiment.

Conclusion

In conclusion, we created a new type of curriculum that integrated computational literacy in the science classroom. The curricular unit structure was designed as a project-based inquiry task connected to an authentic scientific lab experiment.  Students designed scientific experiments on swimming pool chemistry and created code for controlling the robot.  While this was a pilot study, it provided evidence to support further evaluation of the development of computing skills through media like the LHR. Further research should be done to better understand the permanence of computing skills taught through physical science experiments.
